metadata.title: Nanomaterials-Based Nanosensors for the Simultaneous Electrochemical Determination of Biologically I

sections.text: KEYWORDS Ascorbic acid; dopamine; nanosensor; uric acid; voltammetry

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Ascorbic acid (AA), uric acid (UA), and dopamine (DA) are biologically important compounds with various significant roles in human metabolism. AA is a water-soluble vitamin, an important antioxidant and it acts as a coenzyme in particular reactions. AA deficiency may cause diseases such as scurvy.[1,2] UA which is an end product of purine metabolism is excreted in urine and it is an antioxidant like AA. High UA concentrations can cause gout and UA can be used as a marker for diagnosis of gout and other diseases like hyperuricemia or kidney stones.[1,3] DA is a neurotransmitter and catecholamine. It has significant roles in the human body such as controlling central nervous, cardiovascular, renal, and hormonal systems. Lack of dopamine can cause schizophrenia and Parkinson’s disease.[1–3]
Since AA, UA, and DA usually coexist in biological fluids, have similar structures and usually oxidize at overlapping potentials, finding a sensitive, selective, simple, stable, fast, and affordable method for simultaneous determination of these compounds has always been an uphill task in analytical chemistry (Figure 1).[1,4–6]
Amongst a wide variety of methods such as, spectrometry, chromatography, etc. which are used for drug analysis, voltammetry has become the most commonly used and important one in last years.[7] Voltammetry is an electrochemical method where the current is measured as a function of the potential which is applied to an electrochemical
cell.[8] Voltammetric techniques such as linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), cyclic voltammetry (CV), differential pulse voltammetry (DPV), anodic stripping voltammetry (ASV), etc. are explained in refs.[9–13]
Nanotechnology can be described as a science field which handles the matter at the 1–100 nm scale to create functional materials, devices, and systems. Nowadays, nanotechnology and nanomaterials have become one of the most popular research subjects for electrochemistry due to improving physical, chemical, thermal, optical, magnetic, plasmonic, and catalytic characteristics. These characteristics of nanomaterials can be controlled to develop novel and high performance devices, sensors, and systems by adjusting the size and structure of nanomaterials. Owing to its ability to speed up the signal transduction and improve the sensitivity of the nanosensor by enhancing catalytic activity, conductivity, and biocompatibility, nanomaterials are used in designing nanosensors.[14–17]
Nanomaterials which are used for electrochemical sensing can be classified as carbon-based nanomaterials and non-carbon nanomaterials. Non-carbon nanomaterials include e.g. metal oxide nanoparticles, metal nanoparticles, nanocomposites, ionic liquid-based nanocomposites, polymers-based nanocomposites, quantum dots, nanowires, nanoneedles, and gold nanorods. On the other hand, carbon-based nanomaterials include e.g. graphene, fullerene, carbon nanotubes, N-doped carbon nanomaterials, carbon buckypaper, nanoporous carbon nanomaterials, carbon

nanofibers (CNFs), and carbon nanohorns. Detailed information about the nanomaterials which are generally used in electrochemical determination of UA, AA, and DA will be given as details in this review.
Pharmacological properties of dopamine, uric acid, and ascorbic acid
AA, UA, and DA are biologically important compounds which play an important role in human metabolism. AA is a ketolactone that is structurally similar to monosaccharides. AA cannot be synthesized in the human body but has the property of being oxidized in tissues. It can be found in many biological fluids and pharmaceutical products. AA which is a water-soluble vitamin is found mostly in citrus fruits and green leafy vegetables. It is the most chemically labile one amongst all vitamins. AA is found in the plasma, it is excreted in the urine, and it plays an important role in redox reactions in the human body. It is the most important antioxidant substance which is found in extracellular fluid. Another significant function of AA is that it plays a role as coenzyme of some reactions in the body. It is used for prevention and treatment of upper respiratory tract infection, scurvy, mental illness, infertility, cancer, AIDS, methemoglobinemia, and burns. Moreover, in children bone progress is impaired in AA deficiency.[1,2]
UA is the primary end product of purine metabolism and is excreted in urine in humans. It is known that if UA concentration is higher than 7mg/dL, it accumulates in gout as UA crystals. Its antioxidant property and favorable effects in diseases are not well known. UA is a strong hydrophilic antioxidant in extracellular fluid. It can remove free radicals such as hydroxyl radical, singlet oxygen, and peroxynitrite radical. In other respects, due to its chemical-dependent nature, UA acts as a pro-oxidant from time to time and it is associated with several diseases such as hypertension, cardiovascular diseases, ischemic reperfusion injury, diabetes, non-alcoholic fatty liver disorders, spreading cancer, hyperuricemia, gout, Lesch–Nyhan syndrome, rhabdomyolysis, Fanconi syndrome, and kidney stones. UA can be used as a marker for diagnosis and prognosis of these diseases.[1,3]
DA is a well-known neurotransmitter, and catecholamine is the immediate metabolic precursor of norepinephrine. It is found naturally in the central nervous system. DA has lots of critical functions in the human body such as controlling central nervous, cardiovascular, renal, and hormonal systems. It has a significant role in learning, goal-directed behavior, and motor control. It stimulates b1 receptors on the heart to increase cardiac output, a1 receptors on blood vessels to increase total peripheral resistance and as a result blood pressure rises. It increases perfusion and blood flow to the kidney. Due to these increases, the enhancement of the glomerular filtration and diuresis occurs.[4] DA deficiency may cause various diseases such as schizophrenia and Parkinson’s disease.[1] The most important uses of DA are treatment of acute myocardial infarction, cardiogenic shock during cardiac surgery, and septic shock.[2,18]
As biologically important compounds for living systems; AA, UA, and DA usually coexist in biological fluids. Therefore, developing a selective and sensitive method for simultaneous determination of these compounds is excessively important for electrochemical analysis.[5]
AA and DA have numerous pharmaceutical preparations which are widely used for different indications. On the other hand, there are no indications and pharmaceutical preparations of UA which is an excretion product in human body.

sections.heading: Electrochemical methods
sections.text:
In the past years, electroanalytical methods have become commonly used and important one amongst the other methods.[7] In voltammetry; the current is measured as a function of the potential which is applied to an electrochemical cell. Voltammogram is a plot of current as a function of applied potential and is used for getting information about quantitative and qualitative properties of the analytes which take part in the oxidation/reduction reaction. There are various voltammetric techniques and they differ from each other by some features such as type of applied potential.[8,10,13,19–25]
Electroanalytical methods can be classified related to the applied potential type, working electrode type, stripping conditions, etc.
CV is the most commonly used method owing to its ability of providing fast and significant information about the nature of redox processes. Moreover, it gives information about the kinetics of heterogeneous electron transfer reactions, coupled chemical reactions or adsorption processes.[10,13,19–26]
During the potential sweep, the current is measured by potentiostat as a function of the applied potential. The plot of measured current – applied potential is named a cyclic voltammogram.[10,13,19–28]
LSV and CV are both potential sweep methods although they differ from each other in one respect: In LSV, there is only one sweep but CV involves formation of multiple cycles of potential sweep.[7,10,13,19–25]
Square wave voltammetry (SWV) is a leading voltammetric technique amongst present techniques in electroanalysis. It has high sensitivity to surface-confined electrode reactions thus it has become popular in the last ten years. Pulses are shorter and frequencies are higher in SWV so it is a faster technique in comparison with others.[7,10,13,19–27,29]
DPV is a highly sensitive and widely used technique that measures the difference between the current just before the end and just before the application of the pulse. DPV voltammogram has a peak-shaped wave and consists of a plot of measured currents versus applied potential. Measuring current twice and increasing base potential between pulses are the characteristics which make DPV vary from other electrochemical drug analysis methods.[10,13,19–25,29]
The sensitivity of DPV arises from discriminating charging current against faradaic current powerfully.[7,10,13,19–26]
Electrochemical stripping analysis has two steps. In the first step, which is called as preconcentration step, initially, compounds that are in the solution are deposited on the
surface of the electrode. After this accumulation step, electrochemical stripping is achieved using stripping methods such as DPV, SWV, etc. The accumulated substance can also be stripped by a potentiometric or coulometric method. In stripping voltammetry (SV), there are two different linear relationships: one of them is between the amount of accumulated substance and the analyte concentration, and the other one is between the maximum stripping current and the accumulated substance concentration. On the other hand, because of the limited electrode capacity for the analyte accumulation and fulfilling linearity condition only well below the electrode saturation, SV is mostly used in trace analysis.[10,13,19–25,27]
SV has the advantage of allowing the detection of low concentrations up to 10 10–10 12M. SV techniques are preferred in pharmaceutical analysis frequently. These techniques are categorized by the scan direction of the preconcentration and the stripping steps as anodic stripping voltammetry, cathodic stripping voltammetry, adsorptive stripping voltammetry, and abrasive stripping voltammetry (Figure 2).[7,10,13,19–25]

sections.heading: Nanomaterials in electrochemical sensing
sections.text:
In the past years, nanotechnology and nanomaterials have become one of the most popular research subjects for electrochemistry. Therefore, it is important to understand the basic characteristics of nanotechnology and nanoscience before discussing its use in electrochemistry in detail.
In the most general sense, nanotechnology can be described as a science field which handles matters at the 1–100 nm scale to create functional materials, devices, and systems. For this purpose, various nanoscale materials which have different sizes, shapes, and compositions are ready for use.[14,30] What makes nanomaterials popular and advantageous over bulk materials is its improving physical, chemical, thermal, optical, magnetic, plasmonic, and catalytic characteristics which can be controlled to develop novel devices and systems.[15,16] These characteristics have importance in electrochemical analysis to develop new and high performance sensors by adjusting the size and structure of nanomaterials.[14] Nanomaterials have the ability to speed up the signal transduction and improve the sensitivity of the sensor by enhancing catalytic activity, conductivity, and biocompatibility.[17] To determine an analyte quantitatively, a sensor device is used. If this sensor uses a nanoscale interaction for determination it is named as a nanosensor.[16]
Recently, nanosensors have started to play an important role in electrochemical analysis due to its ability to improve the sensitivity of detection.

sections.heading: Carbon-based nanomaterials
sections.text:
Carbon-based nanomaterials have characteristics such as high surface to volume ratio, high electrical conductivity, chemical stability, biocompatibility, and mechanical strength which make them being used as electrochemical sensors
Figure 1. Electrochemical oxidation of dopamine, uric acid, and ascorbic acid. Reprinted with permission Elsevier.[99]
with higher sensitivity and lower detection limits in electrochemical analysis.[30–41]
Graphene (GR) which is an allotrope form of carbon is a single layer of two dimensional carbon and has hexagonal configuration of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms. GR is rigid, flexible, and has a good electrical conductivity at room temperature. It has advantages that make it suitable for electrochemical sensing: It has great catalytic behavior to small biomolecules, it induces electron transfer, and it has high surface area. Different forms of GR such as graphene oxide, reduced graphene oxide, graphene flowers, graphene hydrogel, graphene nanosheets, pristine graphene, photochemically reduced graphene oxide, etc. are used in electrochemistry.[30–38,42–46]
Fullerene (C60) which is a carbon allotrope consists of sixty carbon atoms that create a symmetrical sphere (icosahedral structure) with pentagonal and hexagonal sp2 rings. Owing to these pentagonal rings, C60 can have a closed-cage like form. C60 is a zero-dimensional carbon nanomaterial which has advantageous characteristics such as being chemically stable, metallic impurity free, easy to apply and creating reproducible electrocatalytic responses that makes it preferable for electrochemical analysis as modifying electrodes.[30–38,42–49]
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are tube shaped structures formed by wrapping carbon atoms into graphite sheets and turning them into tubes. Their diameters can vary between 1 and 10 nm while their lengths can vary between 200 and 500 nm.[40,41,43–48]
Figure 3. Step-by-step procedure to construct a CNT starting with a graphene sheet. The meaning of the helicity indices commonly employed in the literature to denote the atomic structure of CNTs is explained. Reprinted with permission Elsevier.[50]
Figure 2. Summary of the relationship between different possible potential programs and the corresponding electroanalytical technique. (a) Chronoamperommetry; (b) Differential pulse chronoamperommetry; (c) Linear sweep voltammetry; (d) cyclic voltammetry; (e) staircase voltammetry; (f) DPV; (g) SWV; (h) AC voltammetry Reprinted with permission Elsevier.[114]
CNTs that are used in electrochemical sensing can be classified as single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs). They differ from each other by having single or multiple layers of graphene sheets and by their diameter sizes. SWCNTs can have 0.4–2.5 nm of diameter while MWCNTs can have up to 100 nm. They are both widely used as modifying electrodes for analyzing biological compounds due to their advantageous characteristics (Figure 3).[40,41,43–48]
The similarity of carbon and nitrogen in terms of atomic size and valence electron structure, allows carbon nanomaterials to be easily modified with nitrogen, thereby improving the surface chemistry and electronic properties of these nanomaterials to obtain N-doped carbon nanomaterials.[38,43,51,52]
N-doped carbon nanomaterials can provide more efficient results by increasing sensitivity for the determination of biological compounds such as DA, AA, and UA in electrochemical analysis.[38,43,51,52]
Nanoporous carbon materials are materials which have pore sizes up to 100 nm. They can be classified according to pore sizes: microporous (0.2–2 nm pores), mesoporous (2–50 nm pores), and macroporous (50–100 nm pores). Nanoporous carbon materials which are used as electrodes in electrochemical analysis have superior properties over carbon nanotubes and graphene. Their entire structure and pore sizes are well defined, they are affordable and they exhibit a rapid electron transfer in electrochemical analysis of biological compounds. All these mentioned features provide them to show a more sensitive sensing performance (Figure 4).[30,38,54,55]
CNFs are a new carbon nanomaterial with properties similar to CNTs. The main thing that differentiates them is the placement of the graphene sheets of various forms as creating more edge on the outer wall of CNFs. CNFs have larger surface area which can be activated completely and they can ease the electron transfer of electroactive analytes. CNFs can be used as electrode modifying in electrochemical analysis of small molecules.[30,35,38,56,57]
SWCNHs are novel carbon allotrope which consists of thousands of graphitic tubes with 2–5 nm of diameters by aggregating into a spherical structure with 50–100 nm of diameter. Their tubular structure is similar with SWCNTs. With their wide surface area, high pore volume, great electric conductivity, and semi conductivity, SNWCHs have taken their place as electrode modifiers in electrochemical analysis (Figure 5).[35,38,58,59]

sections.heading: Non-carbon nanomaterials
sections.text:
As metal oxides are active, cheap and thermodynamically stable compounds with spinel structure, their nanoparticles
Figure 4. Schematic images of various S–porous carbon nanomaterials: (a) S–microporous carbon (b) S–mesoporous carbon. Reprinted with permission Elsevier.[53]
(NPs) which have properties such as large surface area and low resistance are used as materials for sensors. These sensors which can be integrated with nanowires, nanorods, nanotubes, and nanofibers can make the electrochemical analysis more sensitive, affordable, and faster. There are various types of metal oxide NPs such as aluminum oxides (Al2O3), magnesium oxide (MgO), titanium dioxide (TiO2), manganese dioxide (MnO2), cobalt oxide (CoO), Fe3O4 magnetic NPs, etc.[30,60–62]
Metal NPs are structures which have 1–50 nm size are formed by chemically reducing metal salts and binding them to the surface of the particle. Metal NPs-modified electrodes have become popular in electrochemical analysis due to their unique physical, chemical, and electronic features. The most important reason for the frequent use of metal NPsmodified electrodes in the determination of biological compounds in the electrochemistry is to increase the selectivity of the analysis by providing separate peaks of analytes which have close oxidation potentials and which can show overlapped peaks. Metal NPs-modified electrodes are more sensitive to changes in their surface due to their high surface area and enhanced mass transport rates and they facilitates control over NPs surface and functionalization. Most preferred metals for modification are gold, platinum, silver, copper, and palladium (Pd) (Figure 6).[14,30,61,64–67]
Nanocomposites are multiphase solid structures whose one or more constitutive phases consist of dimensions of less than 100 nm. Nanocomposites are used in electrochemical sensors due to their differentiating properties from bulk materials.[30,42,47] They can be classified as ionic liquid-based nanocomposites and polymers-based nanocomposites.
Ionic liquids (ILs) are salts containing organic cations, organic/inorganic anions and they are composed of ions in liquid state at room temperature or below room temperature. ILs have an easily configurable structure with wider potential windows than other electrolyte solutions. Their vapor pressure is neglectable, ionic conductivity is higher and they have great thermal stability, solubility, biocompatibility. All these features make ILs suitable material for electrode modification in voltammetric analysis.[30,42,64]
Conductive polymers come together with other electrochemically important nanomaterials to form the structure called polymer nanocomposites (PNCs). PNCs are highly
electroactive materials which have significant features owing to the synergistic effect of their components. PNCs are used for modifying electrodes; this modification method is called polymer coating. With this coating, conductivity and selectivity enhances, interference effect is reduced. Polypyrrole, polyaniline, and polythiophene are generally used as the polymer in the polymer-modified electrodes which are widely used in the electrochemical analysis.[30,42,64,68,69]
Quantum dots (QDs), in other words semiconductor nanoparticles, which are colloidal nanocrystalline and zerodimensional structures, are a type of nanoparticles. They have started to draw attention recently due to not only their optical features but also electrochemical features that make them promising for developing sensitive electrochemical sensors. Properties of QDs that are useful in electrochemical detection are their high surface area to volume ratios, high reactivity, reasonable prices, great biocompatibility, and small sizes.[30,32,70–74]
Nanowires are one-dimensional nanostructures with nanometer-size diameters. With their high surface area to volume ratios and adjustable electron transport properties, nanowires have come to the fore an electrochemical sensors.[30,42,70,75]

sections.heading: Other nanomaterials
sections.text:
Nanoneedle is a solid material which has 1–100 nm of diameter and 1–20 mm of length with high aspect ratio and which can be produced using mostly CNTs and silicon. They can be used for detecting biomolecules in biological fluids as well as extracellular environment.[76–78] Nanoneedles are not frequently used in electrochemical analysis.
Gold nanorods (AuNRs) among Au nanostructures, which are often preferred for electrochemical detection with advantageous properties, have recently come to the forefront. AuNRs are used as materials for electrochemical sensors that increase sensitivity and selectivity in the determination of small biomolecules such as DA due to their high surface area, effective mass transport properties, and good biocompatibility.[30,79–81]
Recent applications on pharmaceutical analysis of dopamine, ascorbic acid and uric acid
In the past years, spectrophotometry, high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), fluorescence method,

(b) Differential pulse voltammograms for 1.0mM AA, 0.05mM DA, and 0.10mM UA in a 0.1 M PBS (pH 6.0) at bare GCE (A) and NG/GCE (B). Reprinted with permission Elsevier.[63]
Figure 7. (A) Schematic drawing of electrochemical oxidation AA, DA, and UA on graphitic carbon nitride nanosheets doped graphene oxide modified GCE (CNNSGO/GCE) (B) DPV of different concentrations of AA (C) different concentrations of DA (D) different concentrations of UA. (E) Simultaneously increasing concentration of AA, DA, and UA. The insets show the plots of the peak current vs. the concentration of AA, DA, and UA, respectively. Reprinted with permission Elsevier.[100]
enzymatic-colorimetric assay, chemiluminescence, gas chromatography, electroanalysis, and other different analytical methods have been used for the simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA.[82–93] Most of the used methods have drawbacks such as high cost and necessity for pretreatment of samples. When these analytical methods are considered, electrochemical method stands out among the others as a simple, sensitive and high-efficient method for the analysis
Figure 8. (a) DPVs of GCE, carbon paste electrode (CPE), optimal CPE and gold nanostructures modified CPE (Au-NS/CPE) in PB (pH ¼4.0) with 8 lM AA, 2 5lM DA, and 10lM UA; CVs of (b) optimal CPE and (c) Au-NS/CPE in PB (pH 4) with 30 lM AA, 30 lM DA, and 20lM UA (100mV/s scan rate), (d) DPV of Au-NS/CPE in various pH for 8 lM AA, 4lM DA, and 4lM UA with scan rate of 50mV/s. Reprinted with permission Elsevier.[103]
Figure 9. (A) DP voltammograms at Ni nanoparticles modified glassy carbon electrode (Ni/GCE) in 0.1 M PBS (pH 7.0) containing different concentrations of AA, DA, and UA. DPVs at carbon-supported Ni nanoparticles modified glassy carbon electrode (Ni/C/GCE) in 0.1 M PBS (pH ¼7.0) containing different concentrations of AA from 20 to 2400 lM in the presence of 10 lM DA and 10 lM UA (B); DA from 1 to 55lM in the presence of 400 lM AA and 10 lM UA (C); UA from 5 to 180 lM in the presence of 400 lM AA and 5 lM DA (D). The insets show the plots of the peak current vs. the concentration of AA, DA, and UA, respectively. Reprinted with permission Elsevier.[105]
of DA, AA, and UA. However, it is impossible to detect these compounds simultaneously and directly at bare electrodes, because AA, UA, and DA have similar structures and usually oxidize at overlapping potentials without sensitivity at bare electrodes. To overcome this problem, a wide range of electrode materials such as platinum, gold and silver, metal alloys and metal-nanoparticles, conducting polymers, and organic redox mediators were comprehensively studied.[1,5,6]
AA, UA, and DA are compounds that coexist in biological fluids such as urine and blood and have very similar structures. For this reason, they oxidize at overlapping potentials and cause interference effect to each other. In addition, the concentration of DA (0.01–1 lM) in body fluids is very low compared to AA and UA concentrations, which makes it difficult to make a determination with high selectivity. From all reasons above, ensuring that AA, UA, and DA can be determined with high sensitivity and selectivity without interference effect to each other continues to be an important research topic for electrochemistry.[94–97]
In a recent study, Noroozifar et al. studied simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA by CV, using a silver
Figure 10. Hydrodynamic amperometric responses of graphene-coated alumina electrode (ANF-C700/GCE) sensor upon successive addition of 15lM of AA, DA, UA, and other interfering compounds to phosphate buffer (pH 7.0) at applied potential of 0.4 V vs saturated calomel reference electrode. Reprinted with permission Springer.[1]
hexacyanoferrate nanoparticles/carbon nanotubes modified glassy carbon electrode. As an optimal pH value, pH 2.0 chloroacetate buffer solution was chosen. Obtained linear range values with proposed method for simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA were; 4.0 –78 mM, 2.0–150 mM, 2.4–130 mM, respectively, and detection limits were; 4.2 10 1mM, 6.0 10 2mM, 1.4 10 1mM, respectively. The proposed method also applied to human urine and serum samples.[98]
In another study, Kamyabi et al. studied electrocatalytic oxidation of AA, UA, and DA at poly-2,6-diaminopyridine on the surface of carbon nanotubes/glassy carbon electrodes by DPV. pH 8.0 phosphate buffer solution was selected as an optimum supporting electrolyte and pH for determination of AA, UA, and DA. The proposed modified electrode shows an excellent electrocatalytic activity towards the oxidation of AA, UA, and DA within the linear range of 27–1830 mM, 4.16–225 mM, 0.83–10.0mM and detection limits of 5.0 mM, 0.7 mM, 0.0416 mM, respectively. This method can easily be used to selectively detect AA, UA, and DA in real samples.[99]
Sheng et al. investigated an electrochemical sensor based on nitrogen-doped graphene for simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA. The analysis was performed in pH 6.0 phosphate buffer solution using DPV. Acquired linear range values for AA, UA, and DA were 5.0–1300 mM, 1.0 10 1–20 mM, 5.0 10 1–170mM with detection limits of 2.2 mM, 4.5 10 2mM, 2.5 10 1mM, respectively. This work demonstrates that the proposed sensor is a promising option for electrochemical applications (Figure 6).[63]
Zhang et al. studied simultaneous determination of AA, DA, and UA at graphitic carbon nitride nanosheets doped graphene oxide modified GCE by DPV in pH 4.0 PBS. Obtained linear range results for AA, DA, and UA were 140–500mmol/L, 1–20 mmol/L, 10–200 mmol/L, and LOD values were 1.172mmol/L, 0.096 mmol/L, and 0.228mmol/L, respectively. The modified electrode was also applied to urine samples and DA injection, successfully. The proposed modified electrode showed noticeably electrocatalytic activity for the oxidation of AA, DA, and UA (Figure 7).[100]
In another recent study, Yan et al. determined AA, UA, and DA simultaneously with using Pd-Pt bimetallic nanoparticles/poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride)/reduced graphene oxide/glassy carbon electrode and DPV in pH 7.4 phosphate buffer solution. Linear ranges of 40–1200 mM, 4–400 mM, 4–200mM with detection limits of 0.61 mM, 0.10 mM, 0.02 mM were obtained for AA, UA, and DA, respectively. The proposed sensor was successfully used for simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA in human blood and human urine samples.[101]
Nancy and Kumary studied synergistic electrocatalytic effect of a novel solar graphene–nickel hydroxide modified glassy carbon electrode for simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA. In pH 4.0 phosphate buffer solution, the linear ranges acquired by DPV were 150–300mM, 2–15 mM, 0.44–3.3 mM with detections limits were 30 mM, 0.46 mM, 0.12 mM for AA, UA, and DA, respectively. The proposed
sensor was also used for determination in human serum and human urine samples.[102]
In another study, Afraz et al. investigated a modified carbon paste electrode with multiwalled carbon nanotube/ionic liquid/cauliflower-like gold nanostructures for simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA by using DPV in pH 4.0 phosphate buffer solution. 0.3–285mM, 0.1–450mM, 0.08–200mM of linear ranges and 0.12mM, 0.03mM, 0.03mM of detection limits were attained for AA, UA, and DA, respectively. The optimized electrode and method applied to
In another work, Chen et al. studied porous bimetallic alloyed palladium silver nanoflowers/reduced graphene oxide modified glassy carbon electrode as a new sensor for simultaneous detection of AA, UA, and DA. The as-developed sensor was used with DPV in pH 6.0 phosphate buffer solution. For simultaneous detection of AA, UA, and DA, the linear ranges were observed as 1.0–4100 mM, 3.0–186.0mM, 0.05–112.0mM, and the detection limits were observed as 0.057mM, 0.081mM, 0.048mM, respectively.[104]
He et al. investigated carbon-supported Ni nanoparticles modified glassy carbon electrode as a highly sensitive sensor for simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA. DPV was chosen as an optimum method with pH 7.0 phosphate buffer solution. Obtained linear range results were 20–2400 mM, 5–180mM, 1–55 mM with detection limits were 5 mM, 0.1 mM, 0.05 mM for AA, UA, and DA, respectively. The proposed sensor was applied in Vitamin C tablet, DA hydrochloride injection, human urine samples, and fetal
In a recent study, Zhu et al. studied three-dimensional graphene hydrogel and gold nanoparticles-modified glassy carbon electrode as a selective and sensitive electrochemical sensor for simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA using DPV. pH 7.0 phosphate buffer solution was chosen as an optimum medium. Obtained linear ranges were 1.0–700 mM, 1–60mM, 0.2–30 mM, and detection limits were 0.028mM, 0.05 mM, 0.0026 mM for AA, UA, and DA, respectively. To express the reliability of the developed biosensor for detectionn in real samples, the proposed sensor was applied in human serum samples.[106]
In another study, Aydogdu Tig et al. developed gold nanoparticles, poly(2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) and a graphene oxide-modified glassy carbon electrode for simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA. In a recent work, Taleb et al. studied ultra-sensitive voltammetric simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA with graphene-coated alumina electrode. They used DPV method in pH 7.0 phosphate buffer. Acquired linear range results were 0.5–60 mM, 1–60 mM, 1–80 mM with detection limits were 0.59mM, 0.28 mM, 0.47 mM for AA, UA, and DA, respectively. To investigate the practical performance of developed electrode for simultaneous determination of AA, UA and DA in real samples, graphene-coated alumina electrode was applied in human urine samples. They also investigated the selectivity of proposed sensor using different potential interferents (caffeine, FeCl3, MgCl2, citric acid, Na2SO4, NH4Cl, glucose, urea, H2O2, and NaCl) using hydrodynamic amperometry. They observed that interference effects of those species are unimportant for determination of AA, UA and DA (Figure 10).[1]
Wang et al. studied three-dimensional porous graphenemodified glassy carbon electrode for simultaneous detection of DA and UA in the presence of AA using DPV. The analysis was performed in pH 6.8 phosphate buffer. Obtained linear range values were 0.2–8 mM, 1–60 mM and detection limit values were 0.2 mM, 1 mM for DA and UA, respectively. The results indicated that the proposed electrode allowed detecting DA and UA selectively and sensitively in the presence of AA (Figure 11).[97]
He et al. investigated the synergistic effect of graphene and multiwalled carbon nanotubes on a glassy carbon
electrode for simultaneous determination of UA and DA in the presence of AA. They used DPV and poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride)-graphene-multiwalled carbon nanotube glassy carbon electrode in pH 7.0 phosphate buffer. The linear ranges of UA and DA were 2.0–80.0 mM, 10.0–400.0mM with detection limits of 0.62 mM, 0.65 mM, respectively. The analysis was also performed in the human urine samples. The results showed that the modified electrode gives stable, reproducible and reliable results for simultaneous determination of UA and DA in the presence of AA.[107]
Yu et al. proposed selective and sensitive determination of UA in the presence of AA and DA by poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) functionalized graphene/graphite composite electrode using DPV. The analysis was performed in pH 7.0 phosphate buffer. The linear range of UA was 0.5–20 mM with 0.08 mM of detection limit. The proposed electrode was also used to determine UA in human urine samples (Figure 12).[108]
Quan et al. studied selective determination of DA in the presence of AA and UA by nafion/single-walled carbon nanotubes and poly(3-methylthiophene) film-modified glassy carbon electrode using DPV in pH 4.0 phosphate buffer. The modified electrode was also applied to determine DA in pharmaceutical product for verifying the reliability of the method (Figure 13).[94]
Wu et al. investigated porous graphite oxide-modified glassy carbon electrode for selective voltammetric determination of DA and UA in the presence of AA. The analysis was performed using CV in pH 7.0 phosphate buffer. Acquired linear range values were 10–60 mM, 10–100mM

For investigation of validity and reliability of the proposed electrode in biological analysis, human urine and rat serum samples were used to determine DA and UA in the presence of AA. According to the results, the modified electrode showed high stability, good reproducibility, and good anti-interference ability.[96]
Wang et al. studied 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium 2- amino-3-mercaptopropionic acid salt ionic liquid functionalized graphene-modified glassy carbon electrode as an electrochemical sensor for the simultaneous determination of DA and UA in the presence of AA using DPV. pH 7.0 phosphate buffer was chosen as optimal medium. The detection limits of UA and DA were 0.323mM, 0.679mM with 1–600 mM, 1–400mM of linear ranges, respectively. Human urine samples were used for further evaluation of the proposed method.[109]
Li et al. investigated electrocatalytic detection of DA in the presence of AA and UA using single-walled carbon nanotubes modified electrode. SWV method and pH 7.0 phosphate buffer were used. The linear range results which were obtained from SWV were 5–100mM with detection limit of 0.02mM for DA. The proposed method was also applied to determine DA in DA injection solution, human urine, serum, and plasma samples.[95]
Selected of the recent studies are summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
Due to their sensitivity, selectivity, and reliability, voltammetric methods have been widely used in recent years for the simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA which oxidize at almost the same potentials and are significant compounds of the human body. In addition, the use of various nanomaterials, which have unique advantages in the electrochemical determination of biological compounds, has gained considerable importance. In this review, the recent studies on simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA using various voltammetric methods and nanosensors were reviewed. In addition, frequently used voltammetric analysis techniques and nanomaterials were explained in detail.
When these studies were examined, it was seen that the most widely used method is DPV in which carbon-based nanomaterials are most frequently used. In order to investigate the analytical applicability of the proposed methods; mostly, urine and serum applications were performed; additionally, applications were performed to the pharmaceutical preparations of AA and DA. In all studies, it was stated that the proposed methods facilitated the simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA compared to the bare electrode. For future prospects, it can be stated that, on-site analyses of these biologically important compounds would be critical; hence one can achieve determination of these biologically important compounds without going to a hospital. Moreover, electrochemical simultaneous determination of these biologically important compounds can be achieved by nanosensors coupled with novel transducers such as paperbased, channel-based, microfluidic platforms. With these
selective separation electrochemical techniques, many ingredients such as folic acid, xanthine caffeine, citric acid, glucose, urea, and other mostly found important compounds can be also analyzed using electrochemical nanosensors.

metadata.abstractText: Ascorbic acid (AA), uric acid (UA), and dopamine (DA) are biologically important molecules which have similar structures and important tasks in the human body. Since they usually coexist in biological fluids and oxidize at overlapping potentials; developing a sensitive, selective, simple, fast, and affordable electroanalytical method for simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA has always been a prominent research subject. Voltammetry has become one of the most commonly used and important method amongst the other methods due to its high sensitivity and reliability. Moreover, nanomaterials have become very popular in electrochemistry recently with the use of nanosensors in determinations of molecules thanks to unique properties of nanomaterials. This review highlights the most widely used voltammetric methods and nanomaterials in simultaneous electrochemical sensing of AA, UA, and DA; provides an overview of recent studies on simultaneous determination of AA, UA, and DA, and also explains the interference effect of AA, UA, and DA to each other.
